results.content:
There is a lot of documentation on the Internet about regular expressions, but mostly it is too technical for a non-programmer, like me. 
I do a lot of work on my daily job in Google Spreadsheets (which does support regular expressions) and this course opened a whole world of new possibilities to me. Now I can save literally hours of work using the expressions! 
Thank you very much for this course, Edwin!

results.content: Does not cover basics for learning Regex, just briefly goes over symbols and then says "As you can see this is SO EASY" and doesn't allow anytime for actual learning.

results.content: Although I have used regular expression earlier, I had always dreaded some concepts like positive/negative,  look-ahead/look-behind concepts. Your zeal and passion to teach these fundamental concepts in a way that made these topics so approachable and comprehensible made all the difference. I highly recommend this course to anybody who is struggling to wrap their heads around learning the fundamental concepts of regular expressions. Even an experienced user of regular expressions can pick up a few new tricks :).

Even an experienced user of regular expressions can pick up a few new tricks :).

results.content: The instructor seems to make up the examples as he goes along with the course. I would prefer that he create the examples before hand to ensure that what he's trying to explain is presented in an organized fashion.
results.content_html: The instructor seems to make up the examples as he goes along with the course. I would prefer that he create the examples before hand to ensure that what he's trying to explain is presented in an organized fashion.

results.content: He is a  nice very cheery person, but I would appreciate better use of English language.   ( I never say that, so it's very noticeable).
results.content_html: He is a nice very cheery person, but I would appreciate better use of English language. ( I never say that, so it's very noticeable).

results.content:
At the end of the day, I do feel like this course gave me a basic grasp of regular expressions. 


However, the reasons I gave the course a 3/5 are:

1. Edwin doesn't quite explain things like an instructor; he explains things as if a buddy of yours was trying to teach you something. Explanations aren't thorough and at times are quite scattered and hard to follow. Then he'll say, "See? Super easy!", while my brow is furrowed wondering what it is he just said.

2. English is not Edwin's first language, which unfortunately means grammatical/spelling mistakes are littered through the course, particularly in the summaries. I found myself skipping the summaries altogether because they were, at times, incoherent.

3. Edwin mentions again and again that he likes to provide lots of examples, but in many of the topics, I feel that he could have fleshed things out way more. He provides one or two examples and quickly moves on without much range.

4. There are no exercises to do along the way. Edwin shows you his use of regex and welcomes you to follow along, but it would be nice if there were provided exercises we could try on our own.

Do take this course if you just want someone to help flesh regex out a bit for you, since it's a little difficult to learn on your own. I would recommend that you be at least somewhat familiar with programming and have read up a little on regex.
results.content_html:
At the end of the day, I do feel like this course gave me a basic grasp of regular expressions.

However, the reasons I gave the course a 3/5 are:

1. Edwin doesn't quite explain things like an instructor; he explains things as if a buddy of yours was trying to teach you something. Explanations aren't thorough and at times are quite scattered and hard to follow. Then he'll say, "See? Super easy!", while my brow is furrowed wondering what it is he just said.

2. English is not Edwin's first language, which unfortunately means grammatical/spelling mistakes are littered through the course, particularly in the summaries. I found myself skipping the summaries altogether because they were, at times, incoherent.

3. Edwin mentions again and again that he likes to provide lots of examples, but in many of the topics, I feel that he could have fleshed things out way more. He provides one or two examples and quickly moves on without much range.

4. There are no exercises to do along the way. Edwin shows you his use of regex and welcomes you to follow along, but it would be nice if there were provided exercises we could try on our own.

Do take this course if you just want someone to help flesh regex out a bit for you, since it's a little difficult to learn on your own. I would recommend that you be at least somewhat familiar with programming and have read up a little on regex.

results.content:
This course is amazing. The videos are short not because they have little content but because the instructor is clear and goes straight to the point.

As the name of the course states, you will not learn about the specifics of regular expressions for a specific language but the basis and generalities that are most likely shared by them.

I work as an SQL developer and it has helped me increase the speed with which I edit large scripts or tune specific queries.

I absolutely recommend taking this course if you're new or eager to learn about regular expressions.

results.content:
These videos are a bit all over the place and very hit and miss.

There is a mistake in the first section summary (/super/ matches "bmw").

Starts explaining with an antidote about whats on screen (for example a regex for a file), gets side tracked and then gets lost!

Frequently typing mistakes, or regex mistakes, followed by 'You see, it didnt work' and then a correction. Looks unprofessional and harder to follow.

The examples given for the regex are not very clear, and using more real world example would have been better.

results.content:
He does a good job of explaining RegEx from the ground up, not assuming much prior knowledge. I've learned a lot! The biggest negative is his speaking. He, self-admittedly, struggles a bit with English. It's not horrible by any means, but his grammar mistakes and verbal backtracking cause me a little confusion sometimes. Not hating at all. I speak a foreign language imperfectly, so I know the struggle. But it's worth pointing out, as it does hinder understanding a bit.

Highly recommend watching these lessons with a RegEx testing tool open to follow along with him.

results.content: The instruction regarding the syntax was great, but I would have liked to see it put into some sort of context.  There was one lecture in which the instructor used some HTML and showed the RegEx as part of a snippet of JavaScript, but it would have been nice to see a few more examples.  Being new to RegEx, I am not quite familiar with the use of it in web applications, so being able to see it in a context as far as why we would need to match a pattern would help solidify the understanding a bit more, for me at least.

results.content: This course come to the point, simple and useful, I always was afraid about regex, those weird characters could seem intimidating, but thanks to this course I am able to write my own regular expressions confidently. I just saw a problem, the lectures should be more planned, in some points Edwin gets unexpected results because He develops the class on fly that is easily solvable planning exactly the content of each lecture might have. General terms, it's a good course and Learned a lot because I follow the lectures, writing the examples, pausing, tried different things and so on.

results.content:
Dear Edwin. Thank you so much for this course. I really feel you gave us a good introduction into regular expressions. I want to be honest with you: I considered to give you just 4 stars because in some lectures you seemed to make up examples on the spot and occassionaly even needed to fix your own regex in order for it to match the testing words. This can easily put people off if they don't have a good grasp about the topic yet. I would suggest you to prepare the examples in advance and use your great energy on delivering the message. However, it didn't put me off too much and it was just occassionally. Let me tell you why I give you 5 stars: I have never met anyone who manages to deliver a topic about programming in such an energetic, fun and memorable way. I honestly can say I learned a lot about regular expressions and this is because of your teaching style. You also have a very symphatic and lovely character. I booked already another course from you :-)

Keep up the good work!

PS: Another way to improve the course would be quizzes in between the lectures to test our knowledge. It could be to solve a word with regular expressions or see a regular expressions and have a multiple choice for the correct answer. I saw this in another course and it was really helpful.

results.content: I haven't finished the course yet, but already in section 3 I found an obvious mistake in the instructor's explanation for character ranges. As someone who is wanting to learn regex from scratch I shouldn't have to question the logic behind what the instructor is telling me and then waste time confirming that the example provided is in fact incorrect. This only serves to confuse students rather than helping them learn. The instructor needs to spend more time proofing through his lectures so that the explanations/examples provided are error free. Claiming that "I'm human" is not an excuse for publishing faulty lectures. If it was a live virtual classroom session that is one thing... but when you are publishing passive online content there is no excuse for it. As a result I likely will not be finishing the rest of the course and will look for a self-taught book instead.

results.content:
My preference would have been to receive a precursor of what the regex characters mean prior to jumping right into example usages and explaining what your doing as you go. 
Example: Explain some of the basic regex symbols i.e. *, ?, \, 	, \b then their usages. All that was covered in Sec. 2 was a "." Kind of weak.

I also think, from an administrators perspective, it would have been better to search using tools like grep, egrep initially prior to integrating program functions and the like.

results.content: I use R in my job.  I occasionally need to do some simple regex substitution in data preparation.  I've seen R specific tutorials.  R specific tutorials focus on the r regex functions but I wanted a more general explanation of regex.  This course is exactly what I needed. Definitely 5 stars!  I enjoyed the real-world, applied, conversational tone of the lectures.

R specific tutorials focus on the r regex functions but I wanted a more general explanation of regex. This course is exactly what I needed. Definitely 5 stars! I enjoyed the real-world, applied, conversational tone of the lectures.

results.content:
Nice explanation, clear. Intro was a bit lengthy, but easy to skip.

Funny guy to listen to. I practically skipped through the first 50% since i am a bit more advanced but the second part is quite interesting and well taught.

Skipped to last 50% also, since Edwin tends to do live bug-tracking. In a bunch of cases he finds himself in a situation where something took a wrong turn, and says 'ok, so i just wanted to show you that' while he doesn't really seem to understand why he went there in the first place. But i guess that's code. The insight in his debugging technique is actually helpful.

results.content: Very nice and practical course. He explains a lot of regular expressions for entry levels. Of course to become better you must practice for yourself. results.content: The instructor provides a very engaging and cheerful environment to make you want to complete the course.  This course is meant as an introduction, so it is not exhaustive, but it exposes you to enough that you can likely work through the rest on your own because like many such things, the final learning comes with practice.  But, the instructor helps you overcome intimidations and coaches you through.  Good job!

results.content:
Pretty good course - was able to complete it quickly. 

I am using it for google sheets - and some of the examples are not implemented in google sheets (look ahead and look behind). I was still able to implement everything in google sheets.

The only area that was glossed over is the reference parameter in the replacement string. He showed this in one of his examples but I don't remember him talking about it ($n in the replacement string). 

The history of unicode brought back memories. I remember when I still had an accent in my name. I dropped it years ago. 

Mairé

This course is a good starting point in getting farmiliar with Regular Expressions though.
results.content_html:
The course gave a good overview on understanding Regular Expressions. However, the course did not have a very clear structure. The instructor did most of the things on the fly. Therefore some topics were not discussed very in-depth.
This course is a good starting point in getting farmiliar with Regular Expressions though.

results.content: This is exactly what I was looking for.  An introduction and great reference for Regular expressions.
results.content_html: This is exactly what I was looking for. An introduction and great reference for Regular expressions.

results.content: I enjoyed the course. The teacher is very experienced. He kept me engaged and gave me lots of examples to play or practice with.
results.content_html: I enjoyed the course. The teacher is very experienced. He kept me engaged and gave me lots of examples to play or practice with.

results.content: The instructor is clearly intelligent and an industry professional but the videos seem unrehearsed and made on the spot, like he is taking time to understand what he is doing before he can explain it in the video. This is especially hard when there is a slight language barrier. There are multiple syntactical errors made in the videos that are not corrected until later in the video, making it very confusing to grasp what is happening. Instructor spends more time telling you how easy it is rather than making it easy to understand. I walked away with some new knowledge, but most of which came from googling the concepts after his explanation and sometimes helpful examples.

results.content:
I've finished the course. Edwin did a good job explaining regex, using RegexPal. His accent was not a problem. I learned a lot from Edwin. I'm overall happy with the course.

I want to give it 5 stars, but I took off a star off because honestly, things got cringy during the parts where he tried to demonstrate how to apply Regex in JavaScript. For instance, he doesn't seem to understand functions (he tried to just pass more arguments to a function than it accepted). He also tried to use the \ character as a delimiter when initializing a variable with a regex using regex literal notation. He was clearly just guessing at JavaScript syntax on multiple occasions. 

Now, in a Regex focused course, I certainly don't expect him to be great at JavaScript, but these are prerecorded videos that cost our money (like $10-20 sale price for only 3 hours), and he actually marked it at $99 when it's not on sale, so I do expect him to re-record them if he messes up. Also in the introductory slide, he says "Right down" instead of "Write Down". When you're charging $99 for 3 hours of on-the-fly recording, you should fix these mistakes. I feel that it's a testament to how little effort he put into the course, and I think he should have been willing to put in a few more hours of his time, that's all.

I may sound nit picky, but I'm used to TeamTreeHouse's immaculate quality of content, and he does spend a lot of time comparing himself and his course to other teachers and courses (especially free YouTube courses).

So far I have watched: 
1) TeamTreeHouse: Regular Expressions In Javascript
2) Pluralsight: Introduction to Regular Expression (Regex)
3) Pluralsight: Regular Expression Fundamentals
4) Udemy: (This course)

I would rate them in quality, in the order I listed them above. Each provided a very valuable perspective and advantage. Only after watching all 4, do I now, truly feel that I've mastered RegEx.

In summary, I'm happy I bought the course. This course is worth ~ $15 (udemy often has sales so this shouldn't be a problem), but don't pay the retail $99.99 asking price.

results.content: The "baby steps" approach is very helpful. I tried to follow some youtube Regex tutorials but they were difficult to follow because the examples were overly complicated. The concepts are easy to follow and the simplified examples are useful in building more abstract regex.
results.content_html: The "baby steps" approach is very helpful. I tried to follow some youtube Regex tutorials but they were difficult to follow because the examples were overly complicated. The concepts are easy to follow and the simplified examples are useful in building more abstract regex.

results.content: Overall I thought the course was very well designed, nice and engaging. Providing a full amount of information leading from basic to intermediate. Coming from a background of knowing what regex is and how to identify it but not knowing how it works this course has been great! The only reason for the half star missing is that more challenges could of been put in place for exercises but overall still a great course!
